<@UJCHWTMH6> set the channel purpose: Create a research center specifically for the future of coding - a sort of Manhattan Project for the Future of Coding. Milestones not deadlines. No specific targets. Vision not goals.  Weekly reviews of progress and critical peer sessions (ala PARC).
purpose: Create a research center specifically for the future of coding - a sort of Manhattan Project for the Future of Coding. Milestones not deadlines. No specific targets. Vision not goals.  Weekly reviews of progress and critical peer sessions (ala PARC).

text: *A Manhattan Project for the Future of Coding*  30 people, more or less, working on maybe 20-40 ideas.  Researchers would have full ownership of their work. Milestones not deadlines. No specific targets. Vision not goals.  Weekly reviews of progress and critical peer sessions (ala PARC).  Baseball, not golf (to quote Alan Kay).

Here's an exhibit of the type of space I'm thinking of (it could be in the US or elsewhere):
<https://www.casa.it/rustico-casale/vendita/perugia/localita-ripa-alta-collazzone-700mq-33803004>
People would be able to either stay on-site (room and board) or live off-prem and just work there.

Moving to another country for a year to work on this project would be impractical for many of us, for various reasons (finances, job, family). Will you entertain the idea of remote collaborators?

This sounds like the dream. Two questions though. Would someone sponsor the work financially? Like, how would we work on this and provide for our families? Second, would we get further than PARC got? Alex Miller of Strange Loop recently said to me something along the lines of “Computation hasn’t advanced since the 70's”. “Worse is better” seems to be a real problem; how would the this project overcome that?
<@UC21F8Q48> has joined the channel
<@UJG7QQQJW> has joined the channel
<@UCGAK10LS> has joined the channel

I don't think you get the same kind of outcomes through remote collaboration (not until we have robust AR telepresence anyway). There's something irreplaceable about a whiteboard meeting. And as far as jobs go, I think the idea is that this *would* be your job (questions about financing aside). I already have enough trouble dedicating significant time to work on FoC when I'm employed just 2-3 days a week atm. There are just too many distractions throughout a typical week, and escaping to some Tuscan villa in the middle of nowhere is the means to solve that.

text: But either way, this concept seems fanciful because surely most of us are not wealthy enough to fund ourselves for a year of philanthropic work like this (unless you're trying to make a startup). If a bitcoin billionaire felt like funding this I'd be packing my bags tomorrow.

> bitcoin billionaire
This is exactly what happened to the Eve project; however, in the end, it never achieved success, for, as far as I can tell, non-technical reasons. I highly recommend the talk “Against the Current” by Chris Granger. He and his team went down something like this path relatively recently, and achieved an incredible amount, but ultimately didn’t attain to their goal <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WT2CMS0MxJ0>

text: I don’t say this to discourage, only to caution in the hopes we might not fall into the same mistakes.
<@UHP08C1DK> has joined the channel

<@UCGAK10LS> said "I don't think you get the same kind of outcomes through remote collaboration (not until we have robust AR telepresence anyway). There's something irreplaceable about a whiteboard meeting."

While this is true, it's also true that in order to attract the best talent to this project (without using remote collaboration), then you'll need to be able to pay salaries.

Re: Remote vs local. This could also be a chance for the open source philosophy to shine. While I’m not sure all that I think  about open-source all the way down, it has enabled amazing things. I’m reminded in particular of an epidemic outbreak of disease that was rapidly quelled because researchers all around the world posted their results on GitHub and were able to work in parallel.
That said, local is definitely more productive. There’s just not question that the quality of interaction and focus is better when you’re in the same room.

Remote: I've been following the WebGPU project, which is an ambitious open source collaboration between people from Google, Mozilla, Microsoft and Apple. No single corporation is "in charge". They are geographically distributed, communicating via github, email, etc, but they have weekly video/voice conferences, and less frequent face-to-face meetings. That's probably a common model. (Rust is a pretty successful language project. Did they use a similar model?)

Local: A good model is to create a non-profit research organization funded by a large grant from a tech billionaire. In my city, the Perimeter Institute is a successful research organization (in theoretical physics) that is funded by this model. For doing research, as opposed to product development, you need to fund multiple years of research without producing commercially profitable results. So a VC-funded startup or kickstarter funding is not a path to sustainable long term research funding.

The WebGPU team contains sub-teams from the same company though. So it's not 100% remote collaboration, it's more like a team with multiple offices. Rust is (or was) mostly driven by Mozillians who work at the same HQ.
And these cases prove that remote collaboration can "work", but we already knew that (many companies do it). This doesn't provide any evidence that one approach is *more effective* than the other.
<@UE1JQM9HQ> has joined the channel

And the work on WebGPU is like very technical and concrete: standardizing some already working concepts to work in the existing browsers using GPU existing capacities. It is mainly a work on compromise between major web actors. It is very different than work on somithing vague like "the future of coding", with all kinds of ideas popping up here and there that need to be managed to produce some concrete and useable outputs. I don't say remote won't work, sucessful remote work for WebGPU team don't mean it is transposable to our case.
<@U5STGTB3J> has joined the channel
<@UAL7940NM> has joined the channel
paradoxically, a bigger institute with 10 people has more chance of being funded (at 10x the cost!) than an individual
so I'm +1 on this, as long as I can be one of the 10 people!
and it's in London
:smile:
I do remote working for my day job, and it's 80% as good as being there, as long as you have regular physical meetups
and don't hesitate to 'jump on a video call'

Hey <@UJCHWTMH6>, inspired after attending <http://recurse.com/>, I’ve been trying to bring a similar concept to life for two years now — much smaller in scope and objective, but not shy of a similar vision. We managed to do a super-small but insightful prototype event in Hamburg, then an exceptionally well-planned “minimum viable experience” in Berlin (<https://www.eventbrite.de/e/levelup-sprint-ios-development-registration-46756773769?ref=eios>) which turned out to not happen. As a result of that we changed direction slightly (I guess it’s called “pivot”), dropped the plan to turn this into a business, and had a successful event in Budapest with 10 attendees in November last year. And now we’re planning to iterate on that with an upcoming event near Helsinki in July.

At this point I can say that we know how to run a good event, yet we still have no idea how to turn this into a viable business. It’s mostly a labor of love and passion at the moment, “paid” only by the positive change attendees leave the weekend with and the strong feeling of connection we can create in a small group after just three days.

In these last three years my perspective went from “Ah, I can build a better Recurse Center / recreate something like Dynamicland in Europe” to “Hmm, that’s why they decided to do things that way” to “Fuck, this is really, really difficult!”

I sincerely hope you have a good idea of what you’re getting into and am happy to share the things I learned along the way. I would love to see more places like this to exist around the world, where good people with good ideas can work on the future. But there are reasons for why not many places like this exist, and why the ones that do are struggling.

attachments.title: The Recurse Center
attachments.text: The Recurse Center is a self-directed, community-driven educational retreat for programmers in New York City.

attachments.title: LevelUP Sprint: iOS Development
attachments.text: NO MORE TICKETS AVAILABLEJoin waitlist or  subscribe to our newsletter for updates. ***************************** LevelUP Learning Sprint Join us for a 5-day Learning Sprint about iOS development in Berlin, Germany from Monday, July 2nd to Friday July 6th. Ten programmers. Five days. One mission: grow. What is a Learning Sprint? It’s a new format that brings together passionate programmers to share their knowledge in a peer-to-peer learning experience. It’s for intermediate and advanced practitioners who want to improve their skills and techniques in a collaborative and fun learning environment. A Learning Sprint is project-driven and self-directed. You bring your own project and have a rough plan of what you want to accomplish during the sprint. It’s the ideal environment to spend time on that side project you always wanted to work on. Making progress on your project is going to be the most concrete goal you will work towards. However, it will just be the foundation of your learning journey at LevelUP. The real power of LevelUP is the group. Nine other highly motivated peers will join you on this journey and make this sprint a unique and valuable experience. Peer-to-peer learning works without teachers, because everybody is a teacher. We believe that you will learn more and better working directly with other experienced practitioners on the projects you are passionate about.  This sprint’s theme: iOS Development Each Learning Sprint has a theme. This one is about iOS Development. The sprint is not about teaching you iOS Development, it’s about getting better at it. Join a group of experienced iOS developers, hack away on your projects, share tips and techniques, and get dramatically better at building apps for Apple platforms. Bring your published app and work on a new feature. Or finally start that refactoring effort or architecture change. Or take the week to experiment with the new features and APIs Apple just launched at WWDC. Collaborate with other iOS developers and learn their tricks and techniques. And as a bonus, you can receive feedback, pair-program, debug, or analyze the performance of your app with a former Apple Technology Evangelist. Learn Present your ideas and work to others and receive valuable feedback. Discover what others are working on and be inspired by their ideas and perspectives. Learn how others work, about their process, and apply tips or groundbreaking changes to your own workflow. Tap into the unique knowledge and experience other participants bring with them. Teach Share what you know, even if you don’t feel like an expert. If you know something others don’t, you can be their expert. Improve your teaching skills and gain deeper understanding by explaining them to others. Enjoy sessions of pair programming, white boarding, and rubber-ducking, and get ready to learn and teach at the same time. Communicate Collaborate with a small and focused group of motivated practitioners. Participate in a safe and open space where everybody feels welcome and included. Become aware of your own biases and learn to detect and prevent subtle communication mishaps we all get wrong sometimes. Improve your communication skills along the way, almost automatically. Experience Connect with diverse personalities with different backgrounds, perspectives, and levels of experience. Improve your skills through real practice and discover how effective and fun learning can be. Enjoy a fabulous time doing what you love with interesting people. Become part of our Passionate Programmers community, make new friends, and stay in touch. Come to spend time on a project you always wanted to work on. Leave as a better learner, teacher, communicator — and have fun and make new friends along the way. How does it work? We start with getting to know each other, the projects we want to work on, and establish our learning goals. Each morning starts with a quick check-in to find out where everyone stands and where we want to go, and how we can help each other making progress. In six time-boxed one-hour sessions you get to spend time pair-programming, white-boarding, rubber-ducking, studying, collaborating, or focusing on your project. In between there’ll be ample time for a proper lunch break and lots of great discussions. At the end of each day, we wrap up with a quick check-out to reflect on what we learned. At the end of the sprint we present to each other what we built during the week, recap what we learned, and then celebrate our achievements. We wrap up Friday night with the chance to get to know some other members of the Passionate Programmers community. Having finished a LevelUP Learning Sprint, you’ll become part of our community and can stay in touch with your sprint team as well as other passionate programmers on our Slack channel. Facilitators Two experienced and independent facilitators will help you get the most out of your sprint. They will provide guidance, coaching, and just a little bit of structure to set everyone up for a productive week. They will moderate daily check-ins and check-outs, help with planning each day’s sessions, encourage collaboration, and assist you with anything you have questions about during the sprint. They also bring their own experience and knowledge to the sprint and you are welcome to work with them just as with everybody else in the group. Your facilitators for this sprint: Birgit Nieschalk, trainer, architect of human interaction, former IT project and partner manager. Ask her about: teaching and facilitation tools agile practices decoding your own and other’s behaviour (Insights Discovery®) getting unstuck Stefan Lesser, passionate programmer, app architect, and former Apple Technology Evangelist. Ask him about: software development and application architecture agile practices delivering technical presentations iOS development and other Apple platforms and technologies What’s included? 5 days in a professional co-working space in Berlin, Germany Dedicated rooms for the event with high-speed internet access A productive environment to focus and collaborate Guidance and coaching from two experienced facilitators Coffee, tea, water, and healthy snacks A wealth of new knowledge, insights, and perspectives from a diverse team A chance to make progress on that idea/project you always wanted to work on An opportunity to form meaningful relationships with people sharing your passion During the sprint we will take photos and videos for marketing purposes and to share with other passionate programmers. Let us know before the sprint starts, should you feel uncomfortable with your picture being taken. Special Offer Be among the first participants of a LevelUP Learning Sprint and help us design the future of learning. Join us for pioneering this new format and take advantage of our special launch offer: €790,- incl. VAT When? Monday 2nd July - Friday 6th July | 9am - 6pm (Friday party open end) For your travel arrangements we recommend that you arrive in Berlin the Sunday before the event and don't leave until the Saturday after (don’t miss the party!). Where? juggleHUB CoworkingChristburger Straße 2310405 Berlin In Berlin's Prenzlauer Berg neighborhood, with easy access to the M6 and M10 tram lines. Tickets are limited to ten participants; you can join a waiting list, should tickets be sold out. Any questions? Email us. Learn more If you want to keep in touch and learn about future LevelUP Learning Sprints and other activities by and for Passionate Programmers subscribe to our newsletter.

text: If your goal is to muck about with some people you like, I don’t see it being very hard at all. That seems to be the implicit goal of every project that doesn’t have an explicit one, especially projects accountable only to the whims of a few rich techies.

If you want to build a research center, will you have express research questions? Where do they come from, what politics inform them, what is out of scope? Who cares about the answers, how will you communicate them, who will judge them?
I’m not particularly interested in models that center the genius of individuals. Impact will come from attending to process, structure, power, and imagination.
That's the biggest obstacle to this that I can think of.  Remote collaborators would be one way to ameliorate that.

At first, I thought that impact of The Research Centre would come from creating software that solves real problems, and that people will actually use.

But that's not quite right. The impact of Xerox PARC wasn't specifically in the Smalltalk-80 software, it was in the theoretical concepts they developed, such as Object Oriented Programming, and the Graphical User Interface. These are such good ideas that they have been continually reimplemented and refined by many different software projects.

For example, Steve Krouse has this vision of comprehensible Functional Reactive Programming, which is modular and composable, and also easy to understand. A good solution to this research problem might lead to lots of independent implementations in many languages.

But even that concept of impact needs further tweaking. The impact of Doug Englebart's NLS system is usually remembered in terms of certain technologies that he pioneered, such as windows, the mouse, hypertext, etc. But those things are subsidiary to the goals that Englebart set for his project, which was the augmentation of human intellect, on both a personal and on a group level, in order to tackle the important and pressing challenges of the world, using a bootstrapping process to accelerate innovation while maximizing results. [Eg, see "Englebart's Unfinished Revolution", <http://www.dougengelbart.org/content/view/223/>]

So I think the most important thing is to enumerate the goals of the next software revolution. And that will define what research problems need to be solved. And the solutions to those research problems will then be implemented by a lot of different software systems, leading to new software that solves real problems, that people will want to use.

attachments.title: 30th Anniversary Event: "Engelbart's Unfinished Revolution" - Doug Engelbart Institute
attachments.text: Engelbart's Unfinished Revolution - Celebrating the 30th Anniversary of the Mouse and Doug's 1968 Demo
attachments.fallback: 30th Anniversary Event: "Engelbart's Unfinished Revolution" - Doug Engelbart Institute

text:
This is a followup to my point about picking the right high level goals. Englebart wanted to create systems for human collaboration on problem solving, while Alan Kay at PARC wanted to create a personal computer (the dynabook). Both research projects used similar technology (windows, the mouse, etc), but the projects had very different goals.

Brett Victor has a nice analysis of why the goals matter, and about what might have been lost due to adopting the PARC approach over the NLS approach: <http://worrydream.com/Engelbart/>

One high level goal might be (at least for me): democratization of the act of programming. Which means first define what is the essence of the act of programming. Remove all accidental complexity in programming as we do it now to keep only the essential complexity. Then build something on this basis with a focus on the programming experience. Then (and only then) see how the act programming as it is done now can practically fit in the new vision. This last one is because we can't throw away everything that is practically in use, just because of a new "better" way to do things. And also because we can include the old way in the new way, as the new vision of the act of programming will be a kind of a subset (the essence) of the old one.

Well, going back to the example of the UI, Englebart's system was designed to support collaboration between adult knowledge workers, and was intended to make experts more productive. Kay's system was aimed at a single user personal computer suitable for children. When Apple refined the GUI for the Macintosh project, Steve Jobs wanted a single user system, a non-programmable, easy-to-use consumer appliance, the personal computer as toaster. And that became the model for today's graphical user interface.

I'm not sure what modern graphical user interfaces would have looked like if Englebart's vision had dominated, but I use still primarily use the Unix derived CLI, despite how obviously primitive it is visually compared to the GUI, because it's more productive, and because it supports abstraction and automation in ways that Mac-inspired GUIs cannot. The Unix CLI is based on fixed width, mostly ASCII text, and so are the syntaxes of all of the popular programming languages, and that might be related to why I find the CLI indispensable. Englebart's system was based on tree-structured, addressable data structures, and a tiling window manager. There was a conventional keyboard, but you also used a mouse in one hand and a chord keyboard in the other hand for most interaction with the system, when not entering text. The UI was nothing like a Mac-style GUI. And collaboration with remote users was baked in at a fundamental level. I wonder what a programming environment would feel like based on these lost paradigms.

I guess there are different futures depending on your goals. One idea is the democratization of programming, another is improving productivity for teams of corporate programmers, another is improvements to software robustness, reliability and correctness.
I hope the former (democratization) will imply the laters (productivity, robustness...) as a side effect (but maybe not early on).

Well, my own research project puts a high value on democratization. Curv is a language for creating procedurally generated art. It needs to be usable by artists and designers and tinkerers. It needs to support exploratory and live coding. So it is a dynamically typed language. "Fighting the borrow checker" and "fighting the theorem prover/type checker" are not things I want to have in the user experience. If the goal was to prove programs correct at compile time, then I'd use a very different design, which would have a much higher learning curve. I'm skeptical about the existence of a universal programming language that satisfies all use cases.

Of course, it's possible for the research centre to have multiple teams focussed on solving different problems. I'm sure there is overlap to be found in the solutions for democratization, team productivity, and software correctness, and thus opportunity for collaboration between teams.

Indeed, I think one has to find a common ground on for the act of programming and then build different more specific solutions on it (dynamic or static typing, imperative or declarative, functional or other, low or high level, etc.).

<@UJK8MKYAZ> _Would someone sponsor the work financially?_  What I'm thinking of is getting the funding to making it free to live, eat and work there but anything beyond that would have to be self-financed.  I don't know how that would look.  _Second, would we get further than PARC got?_  If you look at PARC, the main locus of innovation in software construction there was Alan Kay, and he has been pleading and frankly demanding for decades that people continue that work.

<@UD3AK9JRF> In my opinion the express research question would be, _"If we learn from prior research but leave all options on the table, what could software construction look like decades forward?"_  And think that would include _access to software construction_ as discussed by Doug and Nicolas here.  I think by definition a success would mean managing complexity without reducing it, and if we do that the barriers to entry for "programming" become drastically lower.

_I’m not particularly interested in models that center the genius of individuals._  Me either and in fact that's the point of creating a group, living, working and collaborating under the same roof.  Here's a quote from Brian Eno on a term he coined.  "Scenius is like genius, only embedded in a scene rather than in genes."  Eno suggested the word to convey the extreme creativity that groups, places or "scenes"  can occasionally generate. His actual definition is:
>"Scenius stands for the intelligence and the intuition of a whole cultural scene. It is the communal form of the concept of the genius."
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d-53tzx69fM>

attachments.title: Brian Eno message - Don't get a job
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Brian Eno message - Don't get a job

text: Note what Brian says here, "The biggest obstacle to that is that people have to have a job."
<@U5STGTB3J> Thanks for that.  I don't know how viable any of this is, I only believe that it's a good idea -- and I think for now that can be enough.

Thanks <@UJN1TAYEQ> for your thoughts, I have reread your replies and found them inspiring (I must have missed something on my first read...). Especially the importance to keep in mind on the high level goals.

And I totally agree with you when you say "I'm skeptical about the existence of a universal programming language that satisfies all use cases." Maybe it is better to work on a foundation for several languages to emerge, each one with its own domain of efficiency.

The one thing I’ve learned in about 15 years of this sort of research is that we can’t do it alone. Some kind of group is essential. Along the lines of “scenius”, I’ve been looking at the way collaborative circles form in the arts: <https://alarmingdevelopment.org/?p=1245>

attachments.title: Roadmap to the Renaissance
attachments.text: How will we escape the current Dark Age of Programming? What will trigger a Software Renaissance? History tells us that major intellectual shifts usually arise not from lone geniuses but from subcu…
attachments.fallback: Alarming Development: Roadmap to the Renaissance

text:
The Corporate Model:
Incorporate the Future Of Coding Institute (FOCI) as a non-profit. The board of directors is responsible for corporate governance. The Research Advisory Council would include luminaries such as Alan Kay and Bret Victor, and would set the overall research directions for the Institute. There will be paid administrative staff, at minimum an executive director. FOCI will be located in a livable city with a significant tech industry, where there are opportunities for attracting talent, and for attracting funding: endowments from tech billionaires, financial support from the local tech industry business council, matching funds from multiple tiers of government. You get funding by providing economic and non-economic benefits to the local community. So FOCI does things. FOCI has a research staff, does research and publishes results (research papers, git repositories). It builds experimental coding tech and does empirical usability testing in a coding lab, with volunteers from the local community. It hosts seminars and conferences. It might run a public outreach program with public lectures aimed at the local tech community. Maybe there is also an educational program. I live in Kitchener/Waterloo, which has all of these resources, and there are a growing number of independent local research institutes that follow this model. So I know that in principle it can be done, if you know how and have the connections.

PROS: pretty sweet if you can pull it off. An independent research institute is a more sensible model for supporting ongoing basic research than a tech startup or a kickstarter campaign, which is expected to produce a usable product within a limited amount of time (after which the organization runs out of money and dies). CONS: a lot of work to get started.

The DIY/Independent Model:
A group of passionate individuals gets together, pools their resources, and you just do it, using whatever means are at your disposal to make something happen. I've been involved with a number of organizations that follow this DIY model,. My local orgs have included a makerspace (with a rented building), and an organization focused on digital literacy and STEAM programming for children and youth. Plus I run an open source research project on github and I'm on this forum. The Future of Coding organization, with its forum and branches in multiple cities, looks like a good starting point.

PROS: lower startup costs. CONS: volunteer burnout.

In the comments, you might mention groups or organizations or even "scenes" that you consider a good model for advancing the goals of the proposed research centre.
A suggestion : starting with the independent model then scale up to a non-profit institute.

`FOCI will be located in a livable city with a significant tech industry, where there are opportunities for attracting talent
There's nothing wrong with that but this sounds like a standard research center and I'm not proposing that.  The reason that the equivalent in art, an artists colony, would always be remote is because it was proportional to how removed from the state of the current art they wanted to be.  Gaugin and Van Gogh, for example, insisted on moving out of Paris to get away from the current scene to start a new one.  The future of coding, in my opinion, will stem from fundamental changes to foundational concepts.  The question of, "What can we build if we throw it all away," is not one that would ever be answered in San Francisco.
An annual festival can anchor a community. “Burning Man for software revolutionaries”
LIVE festival.

The reason I described the "standard research centre" model is to get it on the table for discussion, and also because there is a well understood process for getting funding for such a beast. But I absolutely do want to discuss other models as well.
The one Clojure Conj I’ve been to (last November) was absolutely career changing.

> The question of, "What can we build if we throw it all away," is not one that would ever be answered in San Francisco.

I'm not sure I believe this. Doug Englebart's NLS project, and the Smalltalk project, both came out of the Bay area. SF has plenty of counter-cultural organizations that challenge consensus reality, such as The Long Now Foundation, and the NoiseBridge makerspace, and the Burning Man Project. The concentration of talented and creative people probably means it is still a great scene, even today.

What concerns me about San Francisco today is that it's too expensive. I'm thinking about the price I would have to pay to finance my own residency at a DIY FOC retreat. For the DIY approach, I think the benefit of the remote artist's colony model is cheap real estate.

> The future of coding, in my opinion, will stem from fundamental changes to foundational concepts.

I agree. I'm not interested in pursuing my research from within an academic setting, or as a "20% project" as a Google employee, I see that as too constraining.

However, a "standard" independent research centre is definitely capable of supporting this kind of research. At home, my favourite research centre is the Perimeter Institute. They are lavishly funded, and yet they also have research teams whose job is to burn down physics and rebuild it according to new principles. They have done foundational research on Loop Quantum Gravity, which aims to replace General Relativity with a new theory compatible with Quantum Mechanics. The latest public talk I attended by was by Faculty member Lee Smolin, talking about his project to burn down Quantum Mechanics, replacing or deleting one of the fundamental axioms so that the new theory can be consistent with realism (that the universe exists independent of human observers). They can do this kind of research because they aren't subject to the normal academic constraints of applying for grants from academic funding agencies. All of the filtering of what is and isn't acceptable research is done by people inside the Institute, not by external agencies.

I think the real problem with this idea is finding people with the skills to get it off the ground.
<@UJK8MKYAZ> What were the key features of Clojure Conj worth duplicating by our group?
I'm looking for a north american software conference that caters to people in the Future of Coding community, that I can attend. So far, Strange Loop looks like a candidate. Any recommendations?
Maybe one should organize a FoC Strange Loop preconference event. <https://www.thestrangeloop.com/preconf.html>

text: Strange Loop is excellent.

<@UJN1TAYEQ> I want to give a thorough answer to this, but, in a word, I got the chance to befriend 2-3 brilliant folks and talk with them at length about our common interests and their expertise. I keep up with them constantly through slack and mailing lists, and, taking advantage of their mentorship and free sharing of information, I feel like I've gained 5 years' worth of knowledge in 6 months. <@UHS9K1N6A> is one of them, and I found this Slack transitively through him.

An official preconference looks like a lot of work, including fronting money for a hotel conference room, selling tickets, call for papers, etc. If someone wants to do that, I'll attend.

An easier option is to run an "unsession". You just need to add the FOC unsession to the wiki on the strange loop 2019 wiki page, which doesn't exist yet. Here's the 2018 version: <https://github.com/strangeloop/StrangeLoop2018/wiki/Unsessions>
Anyway, based on the recommendations, I have added Strange Loop to my calendar.

I've been thinking some more and I worry that when I said, "what about a year?," that it's actually just not enough time.  Part of my reasoning with that, is that rethinking software construction is also probably deeply connected to rethinking hardware architecture.  It's a big task and I'm not sure how far you can get even in a year.  And stretching it to be multi-year makes it almost completely unviable for 99% of the types of researchers that would be a good match for it.

Jonathan's  “Burning Man for software revolutionaries”(I love the title, by the way) seems to me to be the next best thing.  It shouldn't be connected to any other conference or meetup, otherwise you'll just get the values of that group leaching into it.

Jonathan over on the general channel said it quite well: _The vibe at SL is highly accomplished hackers interested in advanced techniques._  If I were to choose one conference to go to, it would be SL, mainly because of the people going, not as much for the content of the sessions (for me).

So let's hold a Future of Coding conference, perhaps the first in a series. During the face-to-face meetings that will occur during this conference, we can discuss more ambitious plans to make things happen as a group. To make it "more like Burning Man", we'd like the conference to be highly participatory and interactive. Ideally, each participant is in a position to show off something that they are working on.

"Future of Coding" ™ is a name that <@U5TCAFTD3> sort of "owns", so that would have to be driven by him I guess.
On the other hand, I *much* prefer anyway to call it "The Future of Programming Conference" if the CfP puts equal weight to approaches for non-techies! :smile:

I would be especially interested in a conference where every participant gives a 5 minute lightning talk, blog post, paper, video or whatever so that we have an excuse/context to strike up conversation

I think we should also have much longer sessions.

In the LIVE programming workshop I gave a quick 30 minutes session on Lamdu, only from its live-programming side. I’d need 4 times that to show and explain the different aspects of Lamdu that we’ve already implemented, and this is without describing and discussing future plans for stuff we haven’t yet implemented like structured source control and more. Maybe it should be a Lamdu+Hazel combined session because otherwise it would be repeating everything twice..

When all of the participants are re-inventing the world, they all have 4 hours of material to present, myself included. Lightning talks are really hard to write, but I think they serve a valuable purpose.
yeah, I feel like traditional talk lengths are the worst of both worlds

Has anyone attended the *Salon des Refusés* program?  Maybe it could be expanded to include lightning talks and other types of events.
<https://2019.programming-conference.org/track/sdr-2019-papers>

attachments.title: Salon des Refusés 2019  - ‹Programming› 2019
attachments.text: Salon des Refusés (“exhibition of rejects”) was an 1863 exhibition of artworks rejected from the official Paris Salon. The jury of Paris Salon required near-photographic realism and classified works according to a strict genre hierarchy. Paintings by many, later famous, modernists such as Édouard Manet were rejected and appeared in what became known as the Salon des Refusés. This workshop is the programming language research equivalent of Salon des Refusés. We provide venue for exploring new ideas and new ways of doing computer science. Many interesting ideas about programming might strug ...

text: Wow that looks cool.
Oh, it’s over.
I see that <@U5TCAFTD3> gave a talk on "Visual Denotative Programming".
Yeah I just went! It was awesome! <@UEH6T3RJB> and <@UEJDZRQB1> are organizers
I like the title "Minimum Viable Revolution".
Ha!  How did I miss that?!  So Steve (and others), what do you think?  Is this the right place to do the kind of event we're talking about?

Salon is a workshop at the <programming> conference that takes paper submissions. You would want to propose an independent event to be held at the conference. <https://2020.programming-conference.org/home>

attachments.title: ‹Programming› 2020
attachments.text: The International Conference on the Art, Science, and Engineering of Programming is a new conference focused on programming topics including the experience of programming. We have named it ‹Programming› for short. ‹Programming› seeks for papers that advance knowledge of programming on any relevant topic, including programming practice and experience. After Brussels, Nice, and Genova, this fourth edition will take place in Porto, Portugal, Mon 23 - Thu 26 March, 2020, a charming city that will embrace you as soon as you arrive! The main venue will be the Faculty of Engineering of Universi ...

They’ll be publishing final versions of the papers at some point
You can see papers from 2017 and 2018 here: <https://www.shift-society.org/salon/papers/>
any bootleg recordings Steve? :slightly_smiling_face:
Hi Steve, is this paper or slides available?
Here's my submission <https://futureofcoding.org/essays/dctp.html>

attachments.title: The Misunderstood Roots of FRP Can Save Programming
attachments.text: Are you looking for the real computer revolution? Join the club! Future of Coding is a community, podcast, and research project organized by Steve Krouse.
attachments.fallback: Future of Coding: The Misunderstood Roots of FRP Can Save Programming

text: FWIW, I will be there! I imagine a lot of us will be congregating at Dark's launch (among other spots) <https://darklaunch.splashthat.com/>. If there's enough FoC attendance, I'll create a channel for us to organize meeting up

attachments.title: Dark Launch - Splash
attachments.text: Come join us after spending the day at Strange Loop for a talk from Steve Krouse (Future of Coding) and the unveiling of Dark.  Free food, drinks and chats about removing accidental complexity from backends, the problems with textual coding, coding with live data, eliminating errors in programming, instant deployment and more.Dark is a holistic language, editor, and infrastructure, for building backend web services. We’re excited to show you what we’ve been working on!Doors and bar open at 6pm. At 7pm we’ll have a short talk from Steve Krouse about his upcoming Whole Code Catalog and Paul Biggar will preview Dark for the first time.

text: I will be at Strange Loop as well.

I love the idea of a FoC conference if <@U5TCAFTD3> folks are interested...2020? i'll pitch Honolulu as a location.. I am not much of a planner/organizer, but if someone(s) want to take the lead, I know all the great coffee, research and travel spots in Oahu so I'll volunteer the University of Hawaii Cancer Center and Entrepreneur's Sandbox as host venue...They are in the center of the technology renaissance in Oahu and also right on the water...My lab could be a sponsor as well..

Thanks for the suggestion <@UMVFWPZ36>! This could be a great way to get the community together and keep some momentum going. Is there interest in this <!channel> for attending or helping to organizing a conference in 2020?
Won't be able to get to Hawai'i mind
Bognor?
I would prefer an EU location personally, but overall I'd be interested in attending.
Bognor's at the heart of Europe :smile:
(at least for another month)
I'd attend if in EU :-)
I’d attend if in EU too :smile:
Me too, I'd attend if in Europe!
Yeah the travel to Hawaii is long and expensive for everyone. I much prefer either EU or mainland North America
And I am ok in helping in organizing, if I can.
Would love to help too if I can. And why not Croatia as a Location - cheap, sunny, great travel connections and a booming tech scene :smile:
Shetland. In the Winter.
Count me in, and I can throw my country as an option also: Mexico! a good competition for Croatia, cheap, sunny, close to US, and great food!! :grin: I’m also in to help organizing
I guess we can gather options and then do a poll

I'd prefer an EU location as well, or something not too expensive to reach like NYC.
A poll sounds like a good idea!
I doubt the US would let me in, given all my anti-establishment re-tweets and NSA-tracked reading habits..
I would be excited to participate in such an event, but I'd be much more interested in a symposium or some other forum where the attendees were all actively working in the space.
Can you elaborate on the distinction between a conference vs symposium?
I guess the format (symposium, conference, etc.) can also be discussed and agreed collectively.
I refuse to travel to the States given the current political climate, and I've heard others in tech express the same sentiment about the US and UK as well. The EU would be fantastic.
Canada or Mexico are both good options then :wink:
Co-locating with an established programming conference could make the FOC conference simpler and cheaper to organize.

I'd say conference lacks communication between speakers / attendees whereas symposium focuses more on exchange of ideas? I have spoken at conferences and I feel 1) you need to cut more niche / deep contents to accommodate all attendees 2) conversations can only happen in the 10 min breaks or after party and many attendees don't even get the chance to chat with speakers in more depth.

If I'm presenting I'd be very happy to assume attendees are excited about the same kind of ideas I'm interested in, and to know I can have a deeper than over-the-beer conversations afterwards with them.

I was at the Programming Synthesis conference last week, which maybe was more like a symposium. I would say there were ~50 folks there and ~20 spoke either for a few minutes or longer sessions. I think it would be fun to design a smallish conference (fewer than 100, perhaps as few as 50), and have each person speak for perhaps 2 minutes each, about what they are working on/most passionate about. That way you maximize the odds of everyone connecting with the people most relevant to their work, and you can spend most time in conversation and less time sitting in seats  listening

The Programming Synthesis conference very much felt like it was headed that way, and I would go full throttle in that direction (no talks longer than 5 minutes, perhaps maybe a 10 minute keynote or too)

Two more ideas for brainstorming: something along the lines of <http://StartupSchool.org|StartupSchool.org>'s weekly 1 hour video sessions (where you are paired with 3 other people for a 1 hour video conference and everyone goes around the room giving a quick description of what they are working on; and then another round where you describe your biggest obstacles)

and instead of 1 big conference, perhaps a quarterly smaller "coffee club", where you'd just have a location like EU,Mexico,Hawaii,etc, and you do a "coffee tour" of the city....no formal location, no agenda, just laptops, coffee, and facetime
so you might have 4 events a year with 20 people, instead of 1 event with 100 people
I’ve held a number of workshops in our space. My advice: to make it worthwhile people need to have skin in the game
Can you elaborate? What didn't work in the workshops you have held that will work better if people "have skin in the game"?
(And thank you, I have learn something, I didn't know the meaning of this expression!)

<https://eahotel.org/> is an interesting model. By buying a old hotel in a cheap town, they can provide food and board for £500/person/month which makes it feasible to offer multi-year grants with no strings attached.

> Whilst some kind of pledge to work on useful EA things is required (“I pledge to work towards doing the most good that I can whilst staying at the hotel”), there is no formal requirement for people to produce more value than is put in to help them. Given the low costs involved, it’s a fairly low bar to clear anyhow. And just one major success will make the whole thing worth it.

Avi Bryant has been running week-long catered coding retreats on Galiano island - <https://www.eventbrite.com/e/coding-retreat-may-2019-tickets-53147741325>. That's about what you would pay for a few days in a hotel for a big city conference.

attachments.title: Coding Retreat May 2019
attachments.text: This is a writer's retreat-style event for technologists: there's no schedule, no classes, and no speakers, just 20-30 people each bringing their work to a beautiful natural environment. Each invitee will have a private room in a cabin to work in, and we'll come together over catered gourmet meals to socialize and share our work.

fields.title: Where
fields.value: 120 Manastee Road, Galiano Island, BC V0N 1P0, Canada

text: what doesn’t work: hobbyists giving 5 minute talks followed by people saying “cool”
So when you say "people have skin in the game" you mean people that give talks that are more engaging for them in some way?

I agree that so that this kind of events can have some value, we must try to set something that the fact people gather produces something that wasn't possible when they are alone. Maybe by setting some goals in advance? And organize some workshop (or some other format) on specific topics?

After talking to someone at Strange Loop, I've seriously considered applying to the Recurse Center in New York City. They have 1 week, 6 week and 12 week "batches" where you work on your project while interacting with other programmers. <https://www.recurse.com/> The down side, for me, is the cost of staying in New York.

attachments.title: The Recurse Center
attachments.text: The Recurse Center is a self-directed, community-driven educational retreat for programmers in New York City.

text: A sizeable chunk of the good things that have happened in my life in the last five years have been connected in one way or another to going to the Recurse Center. It's a great community.

By skin in the game, Jonathan means that the presenters are spending a significant portion of their job/money/life on their project, they can juxtapose their work to past work, and they have a lot of dimensionality to their project that they can talk about.
<@UBJGA440K> went there iirc

I'm thinking about this as well, but I probably can only make it for a week, is it still worth it for such a short time?
Sorry, this thread is now two weeks old but, yes, I think of a symposium as being more peers getting together to share their thoughts instead of a presenter/audience kind of environment.
I'd be eager to spend more time with people who are doing the work and talking "shop" rather than listening to people trying to market their results.

<@UNTRC48LC> floated the idea of a "virtual symposium" the other night. you could do something like have 10-20 people give 2 minute pitches each on what they are working on/interested in, and do a whole virtual conference in under an hour on zoom, and then afterwards people can ask questions and continue the conversations in slack/email etc

otherwise let's just do it

<@UE6EFEPTQ> my thought is if this works we can do it again at different times, perhaps quarterly
What, a quarter of the Earth at a time? :smile:
but I'm also open to changing the time....Anything from 5am to 10pm HST works for me
my thought is let's see what works for <@U5TCAFTD3> for the first one....steve, if you can do earlier, let's move it to earlier
haha, perhaps we could do it monthly, offset by 2 hours each time
:thumbsup::skin-tone-3: :smile:
Any late arvo/evening hour in the US works great for Australians
Of which I’m pretty sure I’m the only one :joy:

I have a suggestion on the format. I think live demos are awesome and I want to see them. But the upcoming symposium discourages live demos for some reason.

Also a question: I'm not familiar with Zoom, but can this symposium be recorded?
recording it is obviously a core requirement
I think Zoom recording may be a premium thing, not sure though
I was recently on a livestream at 5am HST, 7am PT, 10am ET, 3pm London time, and reasonable times for people not too far East. Any objections to that time?
That time is good for me of course
By the way, would it be possible to pre-record the presentation?
I don't know if zoom can play a video
If zoom lets you screen-share, then you can just screen-share your video.
And someone could use OBS to record the stream if zoom doesn't offer any suitable video recording feature.
Small, sharp tools people! :)
The free version of Zoom allows screen sharing, and it allows "local recording" of your meeting (onto your computer's hard disk).
<@U5TCAFTD3> Great, 7am PST/10am EST it is then!

<@UJN1TAYEQ> I would love to see live demos too but in practice I see a low % of live demos pulled off successfully given tight time constraints...so I wrote they are discouraged, but of course if someone is highly confident they can pull it off would be fun
we have a pro zoom account and if presenters wish I can have it record

I had a rambling train of thought based on Adriaan's pre recording idea: what is synchronicity good for? We can all pre record our talks and share them here for asynchronous feedback and questions, which can also be given and answered asynchronously. In fact the <#CCL5VVBAN|feedback> channel operates like this already!

So what are we hoping is different here? The main thing I see is that the social pressure of a due date will act as a forcing function, both to get us all to put our thoughts together on our projects, and to get more people bought in on giving feedback. Another benefit is seeing everyone's beautiful facial expressions and having some real human connection -- not to be underestimated for building community and collaboration.

Does this train of thinking resonate? Does anyone have suggestions to get the most out of synchronous and asynchronous methods? 

One final comment: let's not let analysis paralysis derail this. If we can't come to agreement on a different plan in a couple days, let's go with Breck's plan as is
I think a demo day with some "rules"  would motivate everyone to show something. With a deadline and a standard format, we can do it periodically and we generate artifacts of each idea's evolution.
I guess a time limit and a format (conceptual overview, topics to cover, things to show) would make it easier to view many submitions, since the format is similar.
maybe follow the format of a simple paper: title, abstract, introduction, prior art, current status, demo, future steps, discussion.
I think the forcing function itself may be worthwhile, but this is a good point....should we add 1 minute of question time after each 2min presentation?
at 10 talks, even with a bit of buffer, should be able to clock in at under and hour total
that's a good idea <@UBN9AFS0N> that might make things easier for the presenter

"what are we hoping is different here?" The ideal for me is a symposium where everybody is physically present. There are live demos. There is a live Q&A after each demo. There is an opportunity to ask questions about the system being demoed, and have the presenter live-demo the answers to those questions. The proposed symposium format precludes all of these forms of interaction. And you can't have an interactive live-demo discussion afterwards on Slack. With no discussion, it isn't really a symposium. I think that the 2 minutes per presenter and no discussion format is too limiting. How about fewer presenters and more time per presenter, with discussion? Or maybe I should organize another symposium that follows these rules, because we can do multiple symposiums with different formats.
In my experience symposiums are a lot more productive for the speakers, because people that have ideas or interests in that area will come up and chat afterwards....so instead of 3 speakers]
and 3*N conversations.....if we maximize speaker count, it could lead to N*N conversations
i agreee Q&A is often the best part
so added 1 minute for questions after each talk....i would love to try both....but it would also be fun to try and do a whole symposium in 1 hour
:slightly_smiling_face:

I agree that we should pursue both options simultaneously! The in-person conference or symposium is a fantastic idea. The Salon de Refuges is as close as exists at the moment but a more dedicated FoC conference would be amazing. I think we need a core group to commit to being on the organizing committee and then we can get started

The "Salon de Refusés" at Programming appears to have evolved into the "Convivial Computing Salon" in Portugal, 2020. I am hoping to attend. However, a North American FoC salon would be more convenient for me and many others. Maybe in Canada since some people don't travel to the USA. I would like to be on an organizing committee for this.
I would love to attend an in person one if possible. Vancouver would be great, if folks want to do Canada
Mozilla has a cool Vancouver office, perhaps they'd be interested in hosting
<@UBN9AFS0N> should we perhaps offer 2-3 templates people could choose from for designing their 2 minute talk?
yours is familiar to folks in academia, but perhaps there are other ways to approach it that might be more familiar to folks in industry
I like the idea of giving people guidelines, it seems like it would reduce the search space and make it faster to put together a demo
and then people are always free to use their 2 minutes in a way that veers from the suggestions
<@UJN1TAYEQ> PPIG’20 will be in Toronto in Aug/Sep and I am working to have a Salon-like workshop attached.
Well... that's 2am for me here in Melbourne! Might be hard for me to pull off.
One more thing I’d add about synchronicity - it forces you to give a talk on the spot, making your skills better for when you need to present it live! :slightly_smiling_face:
<https://twitter.com/vgr/status/1195940353561387008?s=21> this thread presents some interesting ideas about funding research

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/vgr|@vgr>: Let’s look at Silicon Valley.  Last I checked, Series A, B, C, and D rounds are ~10 million, 20mm, 50mm, 100mm. Might be off by a bit.

So... doubling research capacity of entire university system = 20 As, 10 Bs, 4 Cs, or 2 Ds.

Entirely within the capacity of SV capital market

text: I guess I can't decide if he's saying there's no point to independent research or just that it's hard to fund... It would certainly agree it's challenging to fund, but surely there's still utility in doing the work for those who have the option available to them...? Or is it assumed no one will listen to the result of indie researchers as well?

elements.text: I guess I can't decide if he's saying there's no point to independent research or just that it's hard to fund... It would certainly agree it's challenging to fund, but surely there's still utility in doing the work for those who have the option available to them...? text: he’s saying that it shouldn’t be so hard to fund! that it’s super valuable and relatively cheap with large payouts
and that distributed funding outside of institutions is a model that deserves more attention

Well, those points I would definitely agree with :smile: I couldn't be sure of his true feelings after seeing the previous thread that seemed to say indie research doesn't work <https://twitter.com/vgr/status/1195789557465153536>

attachments.fallback:
<https://twitter.com/vgr|@vgr>: I was briefly calling myself an independent researcher: somebody who self-funds spec R&D on their own ideas. In theory it’s something like indie-research : academic research :: blogging/self-publishing : traditional publishing.

But the idea doesn’t really work.
